citeinfo.title: Community Center Areas New Hampshire 2006
NH GRANIT Database
citeinfo.origin: New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services
University of New Hampshire. Complex Systems Research Center

descript.abstract: This polygon dataset shows the center area(s) of each municipality in New Hampshire. Community center areas were delineated by staff at the nine Regional Planning Agencies based on a common methodology, with input and review from staff at the NH Department of Environmental Services. The approach for delineating these areas focused on key characteristics of the nature of development including the presence of a higher-density development and/or a mix of different types of uses, such as residential, commercial and public uses, core main streets areas and historic districts, higher-density neighborhoods within walking distance, appropriate zoning to retain its current characteristics, and recognition by the community as its center. Municipalities can have multiple center areas, provided they each meet the criteria described. Boundary lines generally follow the limits of current development (rather than parcel or property lines) and may follow significant manmade or natural features that serve as a boundary, such as a major roadway or river.
descript.purpose: This dataset is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.

cntorgp.cntorg: New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000

dataqual.logic: The data is checked for errors and checked for positional accuracy based on 1998 USGS Digital Ortho Quadrangles, 2003 NAIP imagery and/or USGS Topographic Quadrangles. The data is spatially clean having no topological errors or other kind. Centers were delineated using the guidelines developed by the Sprawl Indicators Workgroup. The data was reviewed by both the regional planning associations and NHDES.
dataqual.complete: The data are complete as of the publication date. Any additions or changes to the community centers will be updated as the need arises.

procstep.procdesc: Central New Hampshire Regional Planning Commission (CNHRPC ) Base data collected from existing community master plan documents and GPS data. Additional destinations were delineated from 2003 NAIP imagery.

Lakes Region Planning Commission (LRPC) The master plan and zoning ordinance for each community was reviewed for designations of "Main Street Program" areas, "downtown", or "village districts". Knowledge from regional and local planners, as well as local planning boards were also incorporated. The polygon boundaries were compared with boundaries and patterns observed in 2003 NAIP imagery.

Nashua Regional Planning Commission (NRPC) Polygons were derived from digital parcel data, aerial imagery and existing local plans. Areas were designated as destination polygons based on the Sprawl Indicators criteria.

Rockingham Region Planning Commission (RPC) Town/city centers developed for the RPC Regional Master Plan was displayed in ArcMap over digital municipal tax lot layers. Corrections were made in the original data to better coincide with tax lot size and density. Where no digital parcel layer was available, {Hampstead, Sandown, South Hampton, Newton} only digital orthophoto interpretation was used for the delineation. Required fields were coded. Features were plotted on aerial photo and tax parcel base maps for staff review and comment. Additions and corrections were made per staff comments.

Southern New Hampshire Regional Planning Commission (SNHRPC) The individual towns within the region were sent a copy of the printed map of the last version of sprawl indicators to make changes to the existing or add any new indicators to the data. Planner from SNHPC has also set up meetings to discuss and map the new indicators with community planners from the individual towns. The 2004 color ariel photos where used to map the exact location of the marked indicator. The data is also georefrenced and is also attributed with information

Strafford Regional Planning Commission (SRPC) Originally SRPC staff/volunteers delineated the community center areas from 1998 USGS Ortho & Topo Quadrangles. When available, digital municipal tax parcel data was overlaid on top of the Ortho & Topo Quads for assistance in the delineation. GIS staff heads-up digitized the delineated boundaries of the community center areas. In addition to the hand delineations GIS staff used Historic Digital USGS Topo Maps of New England (archived at the UNH Diamond Library) http://docs.unh.edu/nhtopos/nhtopos.htm to delineate Post World War II neighborhoods. The Historic Topo Maps were georeferenced to municipal boundaries for use in updating the community center areas.
Southwest Regional Planning Commission (SWRPC) Digitized from 1998 Orthoquadrangles at 1:8000 scale.

Upper Valley Lake Sunapee Regional Planning Commission (UVLSRPC) Community Centers were digitized by UVLSRPC based on 1992 or 1998 Digital Orthophoto Quads (DOQ's), from the US Geological Survey and the USDA Forest Service, 1:12,000, distributed by GRANIT.

NHDES collated the community center areas from each Regional Planning Association. NHDES reviewed each submittal for consistency in how the data was presented and what attributes needed to be collected. The data was returned back to the RPAs for corrections.
North Country Council (NCC) Community Centers were digitized by NCCRPC based on the NAIP 2003 Digital Orthophoto Quads, from the USDA Aerial Photo Field Office. 1 Meter Resolution.

Name of dataset was changed from CommunityCenterAreas to NHCommunityCenterAreas06.
This shapefile metadata was edited for clarity and keywords were added per Tufts metadata standards.
procstep.srcused: Tufts University. Geographic Information Systems Center

attracc.attraccr: Attribute information remains the same as given by the author of the data. However, when information is missing or ambiguous, the GIS Information Systems Center at Tufts University researches other metadata sources for explanations. If sufficient information is unavailable, "unknown attribute" is given as the definition. If the attribute has been created through a geoprocessing function, "geoprocessed identifier" is given. If the attribute is known, but the values are not, "unknown" is given for values. Features' units of measurement are determined if not already given.

distinfo.distliab: NHDES is not responsible for the use or interpretation of this information. Not intended for legal purposes. Digital data in NH GRANIT represent the efforts of the contributing agencies to record information from the cited source materials. Complex Systems Research Center, under contract to the NH Office of Energy and Planning, and in consultation with cooperating agencies, maintains a continuing program to identify and correct errors in these data. OEP, CSRC, and the cooperating agencies make no claim as to the validity or reliability or to any implied uses of these data.
